content.title: Aortic Intramural Hematoma (IMH)
content.definition: Hemorrhage within the aortic media without intimal tear or flap, representing a variant of acute aortic syndrome. Results from rupture of vasa vasorum into the media, creating a crescentic wall thickening. Part of the acute aortic syndrome spectrum with dissection and penetrating atherosclerotic ulcer.

key_concepts.description: Rupture of vasa vasorum (small arteries supplying aortic wall) causes bleeding into media without intimal disruption; weakens wall and may progress to dissection or rupture
IMH is part of acute aortic syndrome along with: classic aortic dissection, penetrating atherosclerotic ulcer (PAU); all share similar clinical presentation and require urgent evaluation
Type A IMH: involves ascending aorta (Stanford A); Type B IMH: descending aorta only (Stanford B). Same principles as dissection classification
Indistinguishable from classic dissection: sudden severe chest/back pain (tearing quality); hypertension; may have associated aortic regurgitation if Type A
CT: crescentic or circumferential wall thickening (>5mm) without intimal flap; no contrast enhancement within hematoma; may see high attenuation on non-contrast CT (acute blood)
MRI more sensitive for detecting intramural blood; T1 and T2 signal characteristics vary with hematoma age; useful when CT equivocal
Variable course: may resolve completely (10-20%); progress to classic dissection (16-47%); progress to penetrating ulcer; develop aneurysm; or rupture
Traditionally surgical (similar to Type A dissection); some centers use medical management with close surveillance for stable patients; controversial
Medical management (BP control, pain management) with close surveillance; TEVAR for complications (rupture, progression, persistent symptoms); similar to Type B dissection
Repeat imaging at 1 week, 1 month, 3 months, then every 6 months to annually; watch for progression to dissection, aneurysm formation, or resolution

learning_objectives: Define intramural hematoma as part of acute aortic syndrome
Recognize CT findings (crescentic wall thickening without flap)
Understand the variable natural history (resolution vs progression)
Apply Stanford classification for management decisions
clinical_pearls: IMH = blood in media WITHOUT intimal tear (contrast with dissection)
Crescentic wall thickening >5mm without intimal flap on CT
Type A = consider surgery (like dissection); Type B = medical first
Can progress to dissection in 16-47% - needs surveillance
MRI better than CT for equivocal cases
Part of acute aortic syndrome with dissection and PAU
common_mistakes: Missing diagnosis on CT (look for crescentic thickening)
Treating identically to classic dissection without nuance
Not recognizing as medical emergency equivalent to dissection
